meanings.definition: (adjective) having a greater proportion of costs or benefits incurred or received in the later stages of a process
meanings.sent1: The backloaded project required more resources towards the end.
meanings.sent2: The payment plan was backloaded, with most of the money due at the completion.
meanings.sent3: The backloaded surprise party was a hit, with all the fun saved for the final hour.
meanings.sent4: Her backloaded schedule made her feel like she was sprinting towards the finish line.
meanings.sent5: The backloaded fireworks display ended the night with a spectacular show.

meanings.definition: (verb) to load or arrange in a way that places more emphasis on the latter part
meanings.sent1: He backloaded the presentation with all the important details at the end.
meanings.sent2: The truck driver backloaded the cargo to ensure the fragile items were on top.
meanings.sent3: She backloaded the playlist for the party, saving the best songs for the last hour.
meanings.sent4: The author backloaded the book with a surprising plot twist in the final chapter.
meanings.sent5: They backloaded the event schedule to build up excitement for the grand finale.

meanings.definition: (adverb) in a manner that prioritizes the latter part of a sequence or process
meanings.sent1: The team worked backloaded, focusing more on the final steps of the project.
meanings.sent2: She organized the tasks backloaded, starting with the easiest ones first.
meanings.sent3: The magician performed his tricks backloaded, saving the most impressive ones for the end.
meanings.sent4: The movie built up backloaded, leading to an unexpected climax.
meanings.sent5: The story unfolded backloaded, revealing the truth in the last chapter.
